Dont get me wrong, this man will burn for what he did, and so will i for reading this entie thing. But the sensei character had this bubbly feel to him. Just look at his comforting character design (if you ignore his more kinkier side). And his smile on page 33. I know he is scum, but I can't bring myself to hate him. Out of all the ugly bastard I've seen (which is not many)... this one feels like he can actually become a decent human being, if he tried.

Damn. The teacher leaving was actually a really sweet thing. And, of course, was the correct course of action. 

And, I don't know if this is true, since I have only just now finished reading this, but on page 29. When sensei and Rui were hugging. There was a brief moment in which the screen went dark. I think that indicated that our Sensei needed time for himself and paused time. Perhaps crying and thinking about all the things he done, throughout his head, before resuming time. That's why Rui went, "I thought your eyes were red?" 

Anyway, random rant. But all in all, I'm quite glad that Sensei finally did what he should've done the start; Leave, them, be. Allow them to grow up. You can only pause time on them for so long. You need to allow time to continue, to have meaning in the things you do.

Ok guys, to sum this up: This is not wholesome. The man not only raped her countless times, but knowing that she was about to be the age of having her first period, he thought he could go out in style by “confessing” his feelings, making a speech regretting his actions, but he still knew deep inside he can just find another victim, so he used [The World] and left them for good. Traumatizing the children, and with a bit of fake conscience, it ends it there to fool the reader as if he cared. Is it wholesome because he knows what he did was wrong? Hell no. He still committed the crime and because of his [Stand Power] he left with no consequences.
